Exaggerate: The claim "COVID is over, baby" exaggerates the state of the COVID-19 pandemic, implying that it has completely ended.
Understate: The claim understates the ongoing impact of COVID-19 by ignoring the fact that the disease is still killing thousands of people daily globally.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not acknowledging the complexity and uncertainty surrounding the timeline for the end of the pandemic.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or data to back up the assertion that COVID-19 is over.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes the problematic assumption that the end of the pandemic will be a clear-cut moment in time, which is not supported by experts.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider the alternative explanation that COVID-19 may become a seasonal respiratory virus but will still require mitigation strategies and vaccinations to control its spread.
